instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with fan running wild and laggy
threads.message: Hello guys , have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and the board is spotless , it runs slow and the fans are crazy , I have so far replaced the system trackpad cable , but no changes , given the board is so clean , I have checked out page 44 and compared to a working board and it checked out , now I  don't even know where else to check . Please help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with fan running wild and laggy
threads.message:
Do you have good battery connected?
Did you change both trackpad board and flex?

Try disconnecting webcam.
Run HWMonitor and see which strange values reported.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with fan running wild and laggy
threads.message: I tried a trackpad and trackpad cable , the webcam is disconnected completely

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with fan running wild and laggy
threads.message:
I got the following  that stand out crazily high 

GPU DIE = 128
GPU PROXIMITY=128
GPU DIE 2 =129
HEATPIPE 2 =128
HEATPIPE 3 = 128
HEATPIPE INCOMING AIR = 21
HEATPIPE OUTGOING AIR =128

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with fan running wild and laggy
threads.message:
The corresponding sensors are related with <CHIP>U5850</CHIP>.
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q5801</TRANSISTOR>/03, traces and components in that circuit.
ALS is connected on the same bus, that's the reason I said to try disconnecting webcam.
Also check <RESISTOR>R5350</RESISTOR>/51 and post voltage and diode mode readings for data lines.
